S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Wall Clock Time for Target Accuracy
S5.T2.table:
Dataset Sent140 STT2 Cifar10
Non-IID Non-IID Non-IID IID
Target-Acc 0.71 0.85 0.6 0.7
FedAvg 1139(6×\times) 4660(7×\times) 9833(5×\times) 5040(6×\times)
Fedasync failed failed failed failed
FedBuff 485(3×\times) 2985(4.5×\times) 4375(2×\times) 1541(2×\times)
Port-Urgent 767(5×\times) 2325(3.5×\times) 3000(1.6×\times) 1503(1.7×\times)
Port-Non-Urgent 662(4×\times) 2770(4.2×\times) 3320(1.7×\times) 1668(2×\times)
FedFa-Param 191(1.1×\times) 829(1.2×\times) 2282(1.2×\times) 1102(1.3×\times)
FedFa-Delta 165 652 1917 855
references: In this section, we analyze the validation accuracy in terms of the wall clock time based on different benchmarks that are shown in Fig.

can achieve the same accuracy as semi-asynchronous and synchronous parameter update strategies using less time. Furthermore, the previous Fedasync strategy cannot converge to the target accuracy. We also give detailed results about the wall clock time to achieve the target accuracy for different benchmarks in Tab.

. We find that in terms of time efficiency, the fully asynchronous algorithm is more efficient than the semi-asynchronous and synchronous algorithms due to the natural effects of the system design. The Fedasync algorithm fails to achieve the target accuracy.
To further evaluate the efficiency of our proposed
, we also conduct experiments based on the parameter update strategy, called

, in which clients send the parameter difference to the server, and the server sends the updated parameters to clients for each communication round. The parameter update strategy in which clients send parameters to the server and the server sends updated parameters to clients is called
, we observe that both of the two versions of our method outperform existing approaches, especially for
speedup compared to synchronous methods and semi-asynchronous methods, respectively. At the same time, from Fig.
, we can see that Fedasync does not achieve the target accuracy, which also shows that our method can not only improve the time efficiency but also stabilize the training process.
In this section, we analyze the validation accuracy in terms of the communication rounds based on different benchmarks that are shown in Fig.
. We also provide the communication rounds required to achieve the target accuracy for different benchmarks in Tab.

. Typically, more communication rounds mean a longer period of time is used in the federated learning training process. However, since semi-asynchronous and fully asynchronous federated learning algorithms reduce and eliminate the waiting time to some extent, these algorithms, while time efficient, may require more communication rounds to reach the target accuracy. In Tab.
outperforms other existing approaches by up to
. Combining the wall clock time that is shown in Tab.
also outperforms the existing approaches for the whole training time.
shows the optimal accuracy of the three foundational paradigms within a fixed number of communication rounds. We observe that

achieves the highest accuracy for both Sent140 and Cifar10-IID, and FedAvg achieves the highest accuracy for Cifar10-NonIID. The accuracy of all three paradigms is similar to each other, while our fully asynchronous approach
is more suitable for scaling up the training scales in federated learning by eliminating the waiting time (without the barrier setting) compared to the synchronous and semi-asynchronous strategies.

The number of clients sampled at the beginning of the federated learning training is called the number of concurrency
. Whenever K clients complete the training task and upload the parameters to the server, other K clients are resampled to maintain the number of concurrency
. Therefore, it also means the number of simultaneously active clients. In most federated learning experiment setups,

of the total number of clients. In asynchronous algorithms, increasing the number of sampling clients may lead to worse training results due to the fact that staleness is directly related to the number of clients that are sampled.
As shown in Tab.
, the results of all the algorithms show some decrease in model accuracy as
increases. Moreover, our algorithm is less insensitive to

is highly portable and extensible since it only involves a change in the aggregation paradigm. It is easy to extend other synchronous federated learning optimization methods into their versions under the fully asynchronous paradigm of
. Moreover, such an extension can also eliminate the waiting time and improve the efficiency of the federated learning training process.
We integrate two synchronous federated learning optimization algorithms,

, which is a fully asynchronous paradigm. The synchronous federated learning versions of these two algorithms and the version under the full asynchronous paradigm, respectively, are used to perform the experiments on the Cifar10 dataset mentioned before. The number of communication rounds and the number of wall-clock times to achieve the target accuracy using these algorithms are shown in Tab.
. We observe that the wall-clock time for the whole federated learning training process is reduced to
of the original time with only
more communication rounds consumption. As shown in Fig.
is similar to the original algorithm. However, the training process of the
has become unstable. This is reasonable because the training process of asynchronous algorithms is inherently more unstable than synchronous algorithms.
